thread.title: Trump Today: Deportation fears
thread.title_full: Trump Today: Deportation fears - The Boston Globe

title: Trump Today: Deportation fears
text:
Google+
AP
President Donald Trump at the White House in Washington Monday.
By Martin Finucane Globe Staff February 22, 2017
Welcome to Trump Today, a one-stop entry point for the latest news on the 45th president of the United States.
The headlines
Advertisement
President Donald J. Trump is directing the federal government to find, arrest, and deport people in the country illegally, regardless of whether they have committed serious crimes. The move could have an impact on millions of people. Here’s a closer look .
With an eye on Trump’s crackdown, immigrants who are lawful permanent residents (green card holders) have been rushing to prepare applications to beccome US citizens.
Get Ground Game in your inbox: Daily updates and analysis on national politics from James Pindell. Sign Up Thank you for signing up! Sign up for more newsletters here Protests greeted Republican members of Congress returning to their districts around the country. Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell was jeered by nearly 1,000 people. Trump took to Twitter to blame the protests on “liberal activists.”
The Washington Post looked at Trump’s first days and found that in 33 days he made 132 false or misleading claims .
Today’s schedule
Advertisement
Trump’s schedule includes an 11:30 a.m. meeting with Secretary of State Rex Tillerson, where the two are expected to discuss Trump’s foreign policy agenda. His schedule also includes a discussion of the federal budget over lunch and a discussion with senior staff over the budget. Press secretary Sean Spicer is expected to tangle with the media at 1:30 p.m.
What’s he been tweeting?
On Wednesday morning, Trump weighed in on the race for Democratic National Committee chairman, saying the one thing he would say about one contender, Representative Keith Ellison, was that he had “predicted early that I would win.”
One thing I will say about Rep. Keith Ellison, in his fight to lead the DNC, is that he was the one who predicted early that I would win!
— Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump) February 22, 2017
Trump was quiet on Twitter Tuesday until the afternoon, when he retweeted an article by The Hill on a poll and then complained that the protesters encountered by Republican Congressmen were organized by liberals.
The so-called angry crowds in home districts of some Republicans are actually, in numerous cases, planned out by liberal activists. Sad!
— Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump) February 21, 2017
More headlines
Trump spent six of his first 31 days in office on a golf course, the New York Times reports , saying the White House has thrown a veil of secrecy over the games.
Hospitals are under pressure to reject qualified international medical students applying for residencies because of fears that Trump’s immigration policies may keep the students from entering the country, the Globe’s Michael Levenson reports .
US Representative Joe Kennedy III of Massachusetts is among those who are worried about the prospect of mass deportations under Trump’s stepped-up enforcement plans, Globe columnist Adrian Walker writes .
Conservative media bombthrower Milo Yiannopoulos quit as a senior editor at Breitbart News after a video surfaced in which he defended sexual relationships between men and boys as young as 13.
Residents in a suburb of Stockholm predominantly inhabited by immigrants clashed with police, two days after Trump’s statement about a non-existent terror attack in Sweden and his suggestions that immigration had caused problems there.
ICYMI
Trump said anti-Semitism was “horrible,” and “painful,” as he spoke out for the first time about a rising tide of threats targeting Jewish people and institutions. He made the comments at the National Museum of African American History and Culture. Here’s the video:
A career CIA official said in a Washington Post op-ed piece he was leaving the agency because of President Donald J. Trump.
Alex Jones, conspiracy theorist and nationalistic radio and Internet star, is occasionally a source of information for Trump.
The Washington Post took an hour-by-hour look at how Trump has spent his time as president and found he’s spent about a quarter of his time — in Florida, including those golf games.
The briefing
“It never gets boring. ... It’s been a little while. I hope you missed me.” That’s how press secrertary Spice opened his briefing Tuesday. In the video below, he begins fielding tough questions at about 8:13.
